text:
Terminal>node

const neo4j = require('neo4j-driver');

const driver = neo4j.driver(
  "bolt://44.201.240.207:7687",
  neo4j.auth.basic("neo4j", "job-returns-machines")
);

let query = `
  MATCH (s:Herb)-[v:HAS_COMPOUND]-(o)
  WHERE toLower(s.name) CONTAINS toLower("Ginger")
  return s,v,o
  limit 5
  `;

const session = driver.session();

let result = await session.run(query);


result.records[0].get('s').properties
result.records[0].get('s').elementId
result.records[0].get('s').labels

result.records[0].get('v').properties
result.records[0].get('v').type
result.records[0].get('v').startNodeElementId
result.records[0].get('v').endNodeElementId

result.records[0].get('o').properties
result.records[0].get('o').labels
result.records[0].get('o').elementId

2.2 Generate rsa key pairs
Generate ssh key pairs for each machine.
ssh-keygen
# or
ssh-keygen -t rsa
cd .ssh
vi authorized_keys
This public key is of local host for connecting to each VM. It should also be added.
ssh-rsa  ubuntu@localhost
Thus, we need to add these public keys for each machine.
ssh-rsa AAAAB...NFn ubuntu@localhost
ssh-rsa AAAAB...Hns= ubuntu@node0
ssh-rsa AAAAB...1tE= ubuntu@node1

def create_tuple_list(df):

  df_selected_columns = pd.DataFrame(df, columns=keys)

  records = df_selected_columns.to_records(index=False)
  tuples = list(records)

  return tuples

    if (index >= ind_nomen and index < ind_ref and value != ''):
  
      graph.merge(node_herb, "Herb", "name")
      graph.merge(node_nomen_cat, "Nomenclature_Category", "name")
      graph.merge(node_ref, "Citation", "link")

      node_nomen = Node("Nomenclature", name=tuple[index])

      rel1 = Relationship(node_herb, "IS_CALLED", node_nomen)
      rel2 = Relationship(node_nomen, "CATEGORIZED", node_nomen_cat)
      rel3 = Relationship(node_nomen, "CITE", node_ref)

      graph.create(rel1)
      graph.create(rel2)
      graph.create(rel3)

title: Using Hadoop
text:
2.2 Incompatibility issue
The error message you encountered in Hadoop indicates that the cluster ID of the NameNode does not match the cluster ID of the DataNode. This mismatch prevents the DataNode from successfully communicating with the NameNode.
To resolve this issue, you can follow these steps:

Stop all Hadoop services, including the NameNode and DataNode.
Delete the contents of the directories specified in the dfs.namenode.name.dir and dfs.datanode.data.dir properties. In this case, you should delete the contents of /home/ubuntu/namenode and /home/ubuntu/datanode.
After removing the contents of the directories specified, you need to ensure that the dfs.namenode.name.dir and dfs.datanode.data.dir properties have the same values across all nodes in your Hadoop cluster. Verify that these properties are identical on both the NameNode and DataNode.
Start the Hadoop services, beginning with the NameNode and then the DataNode.

The cluster ID in Hadoop is a unique identifier assigned to each Hadoop cluster. It is generated when the NameNode is formatted for the first time. The cluster ID is stored in the VERSION file within the NameNodeâ€™s metadata directory.
When a DataNode starts up, it reads the cluster ID from the VERSION file of the NameNode it connects to and compares it with its own cluster ID. If the cluster IDs do not match, it indicates that the DataNode belongs to a different Hadoop cluster. In such a case, the DataNode refuses to join the cluster and throws the â€œIncompatible clusterIDsâ€ error.

text:
3.5 How to get different IP on cloned machines ?
I have created Ubuntu Server VM, then clone it again. By checking
ip a
The ip address also the same as the previous VM.
I figure out to use NetworkManager to handle IP address in User-host Adapter Network Settings. You can check the status of the NetworkManager service by running the following command:
systemctl status NetworkManager
If it is not available, install with commands
sudo apt update
sudo apt install network-manager
# check it again
systemctl status NetworkManager
# or start it manually
sudo systemctl start NetworkManager
Then, change network plan
cd /etc/netplan
ls
Open the yaml file cat 00-installer-config.yaml
# This is the network config written by 'subiquity'
network:
  ethernets:
    enp0s3:
      dhcp4: true
  version: 2

section: 3.5 How to get different IP on cloned machines ?
text:
3.5 How to get different IP on cloned machines ?
Firstly, check what the ip address on a VM.
ip a
I figure out how to use NetworkManager to handle IP address in User-host Adapter Network Settings. You can check the status of the NetworkManager service by running the following command:
systemctl status NetworkManager
If it is not available, install with commands
sudo apt update
sudo apt install network-manager
# check it again
systemctl status NetworkManager
# or start it manually
sudo systemctl start NetworkManager
Then, change yaml in /etc/netplan
cd /etc/netplan
ls
Open the yaml file, e.g., cat 00-installer-config.yaml
# This is the network config written by 'subiquity'
network:
  ethernets:
    enp0s3:
      dhcp4: true
  version: 2
and chang it into
# Let NetworkManager manage all devices on this system
network:
  version: 2
  renderer: NetworkManager
sudo netplan try
sudo netplan apply
# check the IP
ip a
